prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO32 IRAS17106-3046
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO(3-2) single pointing observations of the PPNe IRAS 17106-3046 including continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Correlator settings: The aim of the proposal is to map the CO emission in a sample of pPNe disks at very high angular resolution. For this we chose the CO(3-2) line as 1) we will also be able to observe the 13CO line. 2) we do not require the ACA (see below) and 3) we can map the sources with a single pointings. The maximum resolution of ~0.12" obtainable in band 7, is only marginally less than the ~0.09" obtainable under difficult conditions with the longest 1 km baselines at band 9. The the CO(3-2) line will give the best science return.
We place two FDM spectral windows on the 12CO(3-2) and 13CO(3-2) lines respectively. Using 1.87 GHz bandwidth and 2 times spectral smoothing to lower the data rate provides a resolution of ~1 km/s, easily sufficient for our science.
In addition, we want to map the compact dust around the sources. For this we place two additional continuum bands.
Resolution and scale: IRAS 17106-3046 has a disk size measured to be ~1.5" from Hubble images. To properly resolve the disk structure, we aim for at least 0.15" resolution. Although the largest structure is not known, we are intersted to map the inner ~5" (20.000 AU). This requires two main array configurations but NOT the ACA.
Sensitivity: The CO(2-1) of IRAS 17106 was measured by Woods et al. 2005 using the SEST. They found a flux of ~7 Jy dominated by a compact line (with potentially weaker higher velocity outflow) Assuming that the narrow component arises in the 1.5" disk, a slightly stronger (1.5x) CO(3-2) line implies at least 100 mJy/beam, we thus request a ~4 mJy/beam sensitivity for a 25 sigma detection in 2 km/s channels (allowing for a clear detection of weaker emission components). With additional smoothing this will allow us to detect the 13CO at >4 SNR for isotope ratios <10 (as can be expected for relatively massive progenitors.)
The total time for two configurations will be ~1.1 hours.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO32 Hen3-401
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO(3-2) single pointing observations of the PPNe Hen3-401 including continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Correlator settings: The aim of the proposal is to map the CO emission in a sample of pPNe disks at very high angular resolution. For this we chose the CO(3-2) line as 1) we will also be able to observe the 13CO line. 2) we do not require the ACA (see below) and 3) we can map the sources with a single pointings. The maximum resolution of ~0.12" obtainable in band 7, is only marginally less than the ~0.09" obtainable under difficult conditions with the longest 1 km baselines at band 9. The the CO(3-2) line will give the best science return.
We place two FDM spectral windows on the 12CO(3-2) and 13CO(3-2) lines respectively. Using 1.87 GHz bandwidth and 2 times spectral smoothing to lower the data rate provides a resolution of ~1 km/s, easily sufficient for our science.
In addition, we want to map the compact dust around the sources. For this we place two additional continuum bands.
Resolution and scale: Hen 3-401 has a disk size measured to be ~1-1.5" from Hubble images. To properly resolve the disk structure, we aim for at least 0.15" resolution. Although the largest structure is not known, we are intersted to map the inner ~5". This requires two main array configurations but NOT the ACA. See the SG for IRAS 17106 for further considerations.
Sensitivity: The CO(4-3) of Hen 3-401 was found to be ~8 Jy from the APEX archive, with no sign of a fast outflow. Similary, SEST observations of CO(2-1) have a flux of 4.7 Jy. For CO(3-2) we thus estimate 6.5 Jy. Assuming that most of the flux arises from the 1.5" disk, we expect 65 mJy/beam and require a ~2.6 mJy/beam sensitivity for a 25 sigma detection in 2 km/s channels. Simarly, the 13CO will be detected at >4 SNR.
The total time for two configurations will be ~1.6 hours.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO32 IRAS 15452-5459
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO(3-2) single pointing observations of the PPNe IRAS 15452-5459 including continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Correlator settings: The aim of the proposal is to map the CO emission in a sample of pPNe disks at very high angular resolution. For this we chose the CO(3-2) line as 1) we will also be able to observe the 13CO line. 2) we do not require the ACA (see below) and 3) we can map the sources with a single pointings. The maximum resolution of ~0.12" obtainable in band 7, is only marginally less than the ~0.09" obtainable under difficult conditions with the longest 1 km baselines at band 9. The the CO(3-2) line will give the best science return.
We place two FDM spectral windows on the 12CO(3-2) and 13CO(3-2) lines respectively. Using 1.87 GHz bandwidth and 2 times spectral smoothing to lower the data rate provides a resolution of ~1 km/s, easily sufficient for our science.
In addition, we want to map the compact dust around the sources. For this we place two additional continuum bands.
Resolution and scale: IRAS 15452 has a disk size estimated to be ~1-2" from Hubble images. To properly resolve the disk structure, we aim for at least 0.15" resolution. Although the largest structure is not known, we are intersted to map the inner ~5". This requires two main array configurations but NOT the ACA.
Sensitivity: The CO(3-2) of IRAS 15452 was measured by Cerrigone et al. 2012 using APEX. They found a flux of ~30 Jy for the likely central disk component. (stronger components were found associated with the outflow). We thus expect at least 100 mJy/beam. In this case we propose to reach a SNR of 25 and request 4 mJy/beam. Similarly, the 13CO will be detectable with >4 SNR.
The total time for two configurations will be ~1 hour.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO32 Hen3-1475
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO(3-2) single pointing observations of the PPNe Hen3-1475 including continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Correlator settings: The aim of the proposal is to map the CO emission in a sample of pPNe disks at very high angular resolution. For this we chose the CO(3-2) line as 1) we will also be able to observe the 13CO line. 2) we do not require the ACA (see below) and 3) we can map the sources with a single pointings. The maximum resolution of ~0.12" obtainable in band 7, is only marginally less than the ~0.09" obtainable under difficult conditions with the longest 1 km baselines at band 9. The the CO(3-2) line will give the best science return.
We place two FDM spectral windows on the 12CO(3-2) and 13CO(3-2) lines respectively. Using 1.87 GHz bandwidth and 2 times spectral smoothing to lower the data rate provides a resolution of ~1 km/s, easily sufficient for our science.
In addition, we want to map the compact dust around the sources. For this we place two additional continuum bands.
Resolution and scale: Hen3-1475 was mapped with PdB at ~1.1" resolution in CO(2-1) by Huggins et al. 2004. They marginally resolved the base of the jet and the disk (measured to be ~3" from Hubble images). To properly resolve the disk structure, we aim to improve on the PdB results by at least an order of magnitude. For this we require 0.15" resolution. To further map the ~5" size of the jet base, we require two ALMA main array configurations (but no ACA).
Sensitivity: The weakest of our sources, the CO(2-1) spectrum has a peak flux of approximately 240 mJy. The PdB observations reached an approximate rms noise of 25 mJy over 8 km/s. Assuming the CO(3-2) line to be ~1.5x the CO(2-1), we now aim for a rms of 1 mJy in 8 km/s to improve the maps of Huggins et al. (2004) by an order of magnitude when combining angular resolution and sensitivity. We will reach a SNR of 10, which can be improved by spatial smoothing if necessary.
The total time for two configurations will be ~2.3 hours.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO32 IRAS 17340-3757
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO(3-2) single pointing observations of the PPNe IRAS 17340-3757 including continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Correlator settings: The aim of the proposal is to map the CO emission in a sample of pPNe disks at very high angular resolution. For this we chose the CO(3-2) line as 1) we will also be able to observe the 13CO line. 2) we do not require the ACA (see below) and 3) we can map the sources with a single pointings. The maximum resolution of ~0.12" obtainable in band 7, is only marginally less than the ~0.09" obtainable under difficult conditions with the longest 1 km baselines at band 9. The the CO(3-2) line will give the best science return.
We place two FDM spectral windows on the 12CO(3-2) and 13CO(3-2) lines respectively. Using 1.87 GHz bandwidth and 2 times spectral smoothing to lower the data rate provides a resolution of ~1 km/s, easily sufficient for our science.
In addition, we want to map the compact dust around the sources. For this we place two additional continuum bands.
Resolution and scale: IRAS 17340 has a disk size estimated to be ~1" from Hubble images. To properly resolve the disk structure, we aim for at least 0.15" resolution. Although the largest structure is not known, we are intersted to map the inner ~5". This requires two main array configurations but NOT the ACA.
Sensitivity: The CO(2-1) of IRAS 17340 was measured by Ancker et al. using the SEST. They found a flux of ~6 Jy. The component is wide and if ~1/3 of it traces the disk of ~1" we expect a flux of at least 70 mJy/beam (assuming 50% stronger CO(3-2)). We thus request ~2.8 mJy/beam sensitivity for a 25 sigma detection in 2 km/s channels. The 13CO will be detectable at SNR>4.
The total time for two configurations will be ~1.6 hours.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO32 IRAS 13208-6020
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO(3-2) single pointing observations of the PPNe IRAS 13208-6020 including continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Correlator settings: The aim of the proposal is to map the CO emission in a sample of pPNe disks at very high angular resolution. For this we chose the CO(3-2) line as 1) we will also be able to observe the 13CO line. 2) we do not require the ACA (see below) and 3) we can map the sources with a single pointings. The maximum resolution of ~0.12" obtainable in band 7, is only marginally less than the ~0.09" obtainable under difficult conditions with the longest 1 km baselines at band 9. The the CO(3-2) line will give the best science return.
We place two FDM spectral windows on the 12CO(3-2) and 13CO(3-2) lines respectively. Using 1.87 GHz bandwidth and 2 times spectral smoothing to lower the data rate provides a resolution of ~1 km/s, easily sufficient for our science.
In addition, we want to map the compact dust around the sources. For this we place two additional continuum bands.
Resolution and scale: IRAS 13208 has a disk size estimated to be ~1" from Hubble images. To properly resolve the disk structure, we aim for at least 0.15" resolution. Although the largest structure is not known, we are intersted to map the inner ~5". This requires two main array configurations but NOT the ACA.
Sensitivity: IRAS 13208 is the only source in our sample without previous CO observations. As it is a fairly typical source at ~3 kpc we request 2 mJy/beam in 2 km/s channels, which should detect the CO line at at least a 25 SNR. The 13CO will be detectable at SNR>4 after additional smoothing for isotope ratios <10 (as expected for fairly massive progenitor stars and representative from previous observations, e.g. De Beck et al. 2010, A&A 523 A18).
The total time for two configurations will be ~2.25 hours.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
A grand challenge of stellar astronomy is to unravel the origins of the strikingly organized mass ejected from dying stars. Half of these outflows have pairs of strikingly articulate lobes with shapes such as butterflies, ants, and cylinders. Two scenarios for their formation are: the extrusion of a disk from an AGB mass donor by a nearby companion star and ephemeral "magnetic towers" formed as magnetized winds of rotating stars whip its winds into an excretion disk and polar flows.
Thin equatorial disks invariably accompany the lobes. The disks probably remain largely unaffected by the fast outflows that are shaping the lobes. Thus ALMA maps of the density distribution, diameters, and kinematics of the molecular CO(3-2) lines in these disks are the best way to directly trace the origins of mass ejection. Moreover, combining ALMA images with detailed HST images and hydro model simulations can reveal the dynamical connections between the disks and polar flows. ALMA images can distinguish whether the curious shapes of the lobes are formed by thin axial jets, polar clumps, ablation flows that trail bow shocks, or wind streamlines that flow along the inner edges of the lobe walls.
